results_summary: The diet rich in chickpeas, barley, and brown beans (D1) significantly improved total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, apoB, diastolic blood pressure, and cardiovascular risk estimates compared to the control diet (D2). D1 also increased colonic fermentative activity, indicating potential gut health benefits.
population_specificity: Overweight women aged 50-72 years with normal fasting glycaemia (BMI 25-33 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in food consumption, satiation, perceived bowel health, and participant feelings while consuming a diet rich in chickpeas.
results_summary: Chickpea consumption reduced intake across all food groups, particularly cereals, and increased perceived satiation and bowel function. Participants reported health benefits and dietary variety but noted inconvenience and gastrointestinal upset as barriers.
population_specificity: 42 participants in an ordered crossover study.
study_duration: 12 weeks of chickpea supplementation, preceded and followed by 4 weeks of habitual diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a legume-based hypocaloric diet (including chickpeas) versus a legume-free hypocaloric diet on metabolic and inflammatory markers in obese subjects.
results_summary: The legume-based diet (including chickpeas) led to greater weight loss, improved cholesterol levels, reduced systolic blood pressure, and lowered inflammatory markers (CRP and C3) compared to the legume-free diet, with some effects independent of weight loss.
population_specificity: 30 obese subjects (17 male, 13 female; BMI 32.5 ± 4.5 kg/m²; age 36 ± 8 years).
effective_dosage: 4 weekly servings (160-235 g per serving) of lentils, chickpeas, peas, or beans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how volatile compounds from duck stewed with chili pepper enhance saltiness perception through olfactory-gustatory interactions.
results_summary: The study identified 17 unique volatile compounds in retronasal pathways, with eight enhancing saltiness, particularly E-2-decenal. Retronasal odors significantly boosted saltiness perception compared to orthonasal pathways, likely due to interactions with saltiness receptors via hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic forces.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether chili pepper ingestion could trigger vasovagal syncope (VVS) with cardioinhibition in a patient with a history of unexplained loss of consciousness.
results_summary: The study found that chili pepper ingestion led to a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, suggesting a potential trigger for VVS. After cardioneuroablation, the patient's heart rate improved, and no symptom recurrence was observed during a one-year follow-up.
population_specificity: A 60-year-old woman with a 20-year history of repeated loss of consciousness.
study_duration: Not specified (intervention was a single ingestion event)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether chili pepper consumption is a risk factor for perianal fistula in patients with anal fissures.
results_summary: The study found that chili pepper consumption was independently associated with an increased odds of perianal fistula in patients with anal fissures (OR = 2.96, 95% CI: 1.06-8.31, P = 0.039). The results suggest limiting chili consumption may reduce fistula risk.
population_specificity: Patients with anal fissures, including 54 cases with fissure-associated fistulas and 65 controls with fissures undergoing medical treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether strigolactone could mitigate salinity stress in chili plants and enhance their growth and yield.
results_summary: The study found that 20µM strigolactone significantly improved chili plant height, dry weight, fruit length, fruit girth, fruit yield, chlorophyll content, and nutrient concentration under salinity stress compared to control.
population_specificity: Chili plants under no salinity and salinity stress environments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the beneficial effects of fermented red chili pepper on obesity and type II diabetes in a high-fat diet-induced mouse model.
results_summary: Fermented red chili pepper (LFP) showed better effects than nonfermented pepper (NFP) in reducing weight gain, liver and testicular fat, cholesterol, triglycerides, fasting glucose, insulin resistance, and inflammatory markers. LFP also improved gut barrier integrity without causing damage to the stomach or colon.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese type II diabetic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of silica nanoparticles (SiO2-NPs) and Bacillus cereus-Amazcala (B.c-A) on chili pepper plant growth, physiological characteristics, and antioxidant enzymatic activity under greenhouse conditions.
results_summary: The co-application of SiO2-NPs (100 ppm) and B.c-A improved chili pepper growth, increasing seed germination, plant height, leaf count, fruit yield, and antioxidant enzyme activities (CAT and PAL), indicating enhanced plant immunity and growth promotion.
population_specificity: Chili pepper plants under greenhouse conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal high-voltage electric field polarization treatment parameters (voltage and time) for enhancing the viability of dried chili pepper seeds.
results_summary: Negative-voltage polarization was most effective, with optimal parameters of 12.08 kV and 30.32 s, reducing seed conductivity to 159.87 uS/(cm g). Germination potential, rate, index, and vigor significantly improved compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Dried chili pepper seeds
effective_dosage: Output voltage of 12.08 kV and polarization time of 30.32 s

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal enzyme-assisted extraction conditions for capsaicinoids and phenolic compounds from Habanero chili pepper seeds and evaluate their anti-inflammatory activity.
results_summary: The study found that enzyme-assisted extraction improved the recovery of bioactive compounds, with the highest anti-inflammatory response reducing nitric oxide production by 22.56%. There was a correlation between capsaicinoid extraction and anti-inflammatory effects, though the correlations were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Murine macrophages (RAW 264.7 cell culture)
effective_dosage: Not specified (extraction conditions varied by temperature, enzyme concentration, and time)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of capsaicin and phenolic compounds from Habanero chili pepper seeds on cytokine concentrations in LPS-stimulated murine macrophages.
results_summary: The study found that chili pepper seed extracts, particularly those obtained at 30°C and 120 minutes, exhibited anti-inflammatory effects comparable to synthetic drugs like indomethacin and dexamethasone. Vanillic acid was the most abundant phenolic, and other compounds like salicylic, protocatechuic, and trans-cinnamic acids also contributed to the anti-inflammatory activity, while capsaicin and chlorogenic acid showed immunostimulant potential.
population_specificity: Murine macrophages (RAW 264.7 cells)
effective_dosage: Extracts obtained at 1:15 (w:v) proportion with 2,500 UI/L cellulase

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms of capsaicin in chili peppers and its potential therapeutic roles in attenuating fibrosis and preventing malignant transformation in oral submucous fibrosis (OSF).
results_summary: The study found that capsaicin activates TRPV-1 receptors, leading to antifibrotic effects by upregulating antioxidant enzymes, reducing inflammation, and suppressing collagen formation. It also demonstrated anticarcinogenic properties by modulating immune responses and promoting apoptosis.
population_specificity: Patients with oral submucous fibrosis (OSF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of capsaicin in reversing UV-induced skin damage and its potential as an anti-skin aging agent.
results_summary: Capsaicin reversed UV-induced skin damage by reducing ROS generation, blocking collagen synthesis reduction, and inhibiting MMP expression in dermal fibroblasts. The effects were dose-dependent and mediated independently of the TRPV1 receptor.
population_specificity: Cultured dermal fibroblasts and in vivo models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the association between chili pepper intake and all-cause, cardiovascular disease (CVD)-specific, and cancer-specific mortality using a meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that chili pepper consumption significantly reduced the risk of all-cause mortality (HR: 0.87), CVD-specific mortality (HR: 0.89), and cancer-specific mortality (HR: 0.92) compared to rare or no consumption. The results were consistent across studies with minimal heterogeneity.
population_specificity: 564,748 participants from four prospective cohort studies.
effective_dosage: Consumption defined as "ever or more than once a week."
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up duration not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two nanostructured silica materials (SBA-15 and SBA-16) on chili pepper growth, performance, and cold tolerance under greenhouse conditions.
results_summary: SBA-15 at 50 ppm and 100 ppm significantly increased seedling height (up to 8-fold) and improved growth performance, while SBA-16 showed negative effects on plant height and stem diameter. Both materials exhibited hormetic effects, enhancing cold tolerance without phytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Chili pepper (Capsicum annuum L.) plants grown under greenhouse conditions.
effective_dosage: 20, 50, and 100 ppm applied foliarly or by imbibition; higher concentrations (100, 1000, and 200 ppm) for phytotoxicity tests.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but treatments were applied weekly or biweekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different concentrations of 1-MCP on the nutritional quality, antioxidant enzyme activities, and volatile compounds of "Hangjiao No.2" chili pepper during storage.
results_summary: 1-MCP treatment maintained fruit quality by enhancing antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, POD, CAT), reducing MDA accumulation, and preserving volatile aromas, with 1.0 μl L-1 showing the best preservative effect. The treatment also delayed vitamin C and protein decline, reduced nitrate levels, and suppressed volatile compound degradation compared to the control.
population_specificity: "Hangjiao No.2" chili pepper fruit during storage at ambient temperature.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of foliar ZnSO4 application in managing Alternaria leaf spot disease in chili pepper plants and its impact on plant growth and physiological traits.
results_summary: ZnSO4 inhibited fungal growth in vitro and reduced disease incidence by 77% in vivo, improving antioxidant and defense enzyme activities in chili pepper plants. The treatment also mitigated disease-induced reductions in plant growth and physiological traits.
population_specificity: Chili pepper plants infected with Alternaria alternata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different concentrations of amino acid water-soluble fertilizer on the physiological characteristics, yield, and quality of pepper plants.
results_summary: The study found that low-concentration (1.8 kg) amino acid water-soluble fertilizer improved physiological characteristics (e.g., chlorophyll content) and fruit quality (e.g., capsaicin, vitamin C), while higher concentrations (2.7 kg, 3.6 kg) enhanced yield and root activity. The 1.8 kg treatment was most effective for overall quality improvements.
population_specificity: Pepper plants (Capsicum annuum) grown in Lintao county, Gansu province, China.
effective_dosage: 1.8 kg, 2.7 kg, and 3.6 kg of amino acid water-soluble fertilizer applied via furrow method.
study_duration: Applied at 6 weeks after planting (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ethephon application on chili pepper ripening, quality properties, and residue levels to optimize commercial harvest, color, and flavor.
results_summary: Ethephon treatment significantly improved color (increased L* and a* values and capsanthin concentration), reduced chlorophyll content, promoted capsaicin synthesis, and decreased soluble sugar content. The maximum ethephon residue was below permissible levels and decreased with prolonged harvest time.
population_specificity: Chili peppers (specific types not detailed).
effective_dosage: Single ethephon treatment (specific dosage not provided).
study_duration: Pre-harvest ripening period (specific duration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of UV-B exposure on chili pepper plant performance, phenolic compound production, and gene expression related to drought stress response.
results_summary: UV-B exposure reduced stem length, stem dry weight, and floral primordia, while increasing flavonoids and specific phenolic compounds in leaves. UV-B did not induce significant drought tolerance, but it altered gene expression related to stress response.
population_specificity: Chili pepper plants (Capsicum annuum, cv. 'Coronel')

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different water qualities, including disinfected water, on the growth, fruit production, and secondary metabolite composition of Chili Pepper (Capsicum annuum).
results_summary: The study found that disinfected water (50% and 70% DW/TAW) improved growth times, fruit quantity, and increased secondary metabolites like phenols and flavonoids in Chili Pepper, with no detected traces of metals or harmful microorganisms.
population_specificity: Crop models (Lactuca sativa, Coriandrum sativum, and Capsicum annuum) under controlled watering conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define developmental stages of jalapeño chili pepper flowers and analyze the effects of gibberellin treatments on flower development and gene expression.
results_summary: The study identified nine stages of flower development in jalapeño chili pepper and found that gibberellin treatments affected ovary tissue histology and increased expression of CaGA2ox1 and CaGID1b genes, suggesting a role in growth promotion.
population_specificity: Jalapeño chili pepper (cultivar Huichol) flowers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if chili consumption increases symptoms of acute anal fissures, such as pain, burning, and pruritus.
results_summary: The study found that chili consumption significantly increased pain and burning sensations in patients with acute anal fissures compared to placebo, with most patients preferring placebo for symptom relief.
population_specificity: Patients with acute anal fissures (43 completed the trial).
study_duration: One week per treatment phase (two weeks total with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chili consumption exacerbates symptoms of acute anal fissures, such as pain, burning, and pruritus.
results_summary: The study found that chili consumption significantly increased pain and burning sensations in patients with acute anal fissures compared to placebo, with most patients preferring placebo for symptom relief.
population_specificity: Patients with acute anal fissures (43 completed the trial).
study_duration: 1 week per treatment phase (2 weeks total with crossover)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether paromomycin could control Phytophthora blight and soft rot diseases in chili pepper plants and assess its effects on plant growth and defense mechanisms.
results_summary: Paromomycin significantly reduced disease severity in chili pepper plants, with foliar spray showing an 8% severity compared to 83% in controls. It also promoted plant growth and increased chlorophyll content while inducing resistance via PR gene expression.
population_specificity: Chili pepper plants (Capsicum annum L.) infected with Phytophthora capsici and Pectobacterium carotovorum.
effective_dosage: 1.0 ppm (foliar spray/soil drench) and 1.0 μg/ml (infiltration/soil drench).
study_duration: Treatment applied 7 days prior to inoculation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the CaATL1 gene in pathogen defense responses in chili pepper plants.
results_summary: The study found that CaATL1 expression was induced in resistant responses to bacterial and viral pathogens, localized to nuclei, and enhanced disease resistance in transgenic tomato plants. Overexpression of CaATL1 improved resistance against bacterial and oomycete pathogens.
population_specificity: Chili pepper plants (Capsicum annuum L. Bukang) and transgenic tomato plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the role of the CaWRKY2 gene in pepper plants' defense responses to biotic and abiotic stresses.
results_summary: The study found that CaWRKY2 is a pathogen-inducible transcription factor activated during incompatible interactions with pathogens, wounding, and ethephon treatment, suggesting its role in early defense responses. CaWRKY2 was localized to the nucleus and exhibited transcriptional activation activity in yeast.
population_specificity: Pepper plants (Capsicum annuum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether red hot chili pepper exacerbates hemorrhoidal symptoms in patients with symptomatic hemorrhoids.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant effects of red hot chili pepper on hemorrhoidal symptoms, with symptom scores remaining unchanged after both placebo and chili pepper treatment. The conclusion was that there is no evidence to suggest chili pepper worsens hemorrhoidal symptoms.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with second-degree and third-degree symptomatic hemorrhoids.
effective_dosage: Single dose of red hot chili powder in a capsule during lunch (specific amount not detailed).
study_duration: 48 hours post-treatment assessment, with a one-week crossover period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of chili pepper as a complementary therapy for managing ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that chili pepper, among other medicinal herbs, has shown promising results in UC management, but specific findings or data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with ulcerative colitis (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional and health benefits of chili pepper as part of the Mediterranean diet, focusing on its bioactive compounds and potential anti-inflammatory, anti-microbial, and anti-oxidative effects.
results_summary: The study highlights that chili pepper, as a component of the Mediterranean diet, contributes beneficial molecules like polyphenols, vitamins, and flavonoids, which exert anti-inflammatory, anti-microbial, and anti-oxidative actions. However, specific clinical outcomes or mechanistic details for chili pepper alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Mediterranean populations following a diet rich in plant-based foods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the beneficial role of capsaicin in gastrointestinal (GI) health, its mechanisms of action, and its preventive/therapeutic potential for GI diseases.
results_summary: The study found that dietary capsaicin affects the GI tract via TRPV1-dependent and independent mechanisms, with appropriate doses likely beneficial for GI health and disease prevention/treatment, though high doses can be harmful.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the pathways by which chili (capsaicin) contributes to weight loss and its potential benefits for obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disorders.
results_summary: Chili intake facilitates weight loss by enhancing fat metabolism, energy expenditure, and thermogenesis via TRPV1 activation and Brown Adipose Tissue stimulation. It also improves insulin control, supporting weight management and metabolic health.
population_specificity: Humans (general, no specific subpopulation mentioned)
effective_dosage: Wide range (single meal to continuous uptake for up to 12 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavor compounds from chili pepper-containing foods transfer into breast milk and whether infants can perceive them.
results_summary: Piperine from pepper was detected in breast milk but at concentrations far below the human taste threshold, suggesting infants may not perceive it directly. Frequent exposure to sub-threshold levels might contribute to increased tolerance later in life.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding mothers and their nurslings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (consumption of a customary curry dish).
study_duration: Milk samples collected within 1 hour after consumption.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether chili pepper, as a natural product, has potential in the prevention and treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The abstract mentions chili pepper as one of several natural products showing potential for AD prevention and treatment, but no specific results or effects are detailed.
population_specificity: Elderly people with or at risk of Alzheimer's disease (not explicitly stated but implied).

study_goal: The researchers examined historical mixtures used to induce sneezing, focusing on the role of TRP channels, including the chili pepper receptor (TRPV1), in this reflex.
results_summary: The study found that sneezing is associated with the activation of TRPV1 (the chili pepper receptor) by capsaicin, suggesting its role in the sneeze reflex. Historical remedies often included TRP channel modulators like capsaicin to induce sneezing.
population_specificity: Not specified (historical and physiological context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether continuous oral ingestion of capsinoids from nonpungent chili pepper alleviates age-related brain inflammation and improves physical activity in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that capsinoids reduce body fat mass, promote metabolism, and improve complaints of chills, with potential anti-inflammatory effects, but specific results from the intervention were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (mean age 74.1 ± 7.7 years, range 52-87; 17 male, 52 female).
effective_dosage: 9 mg of capsinoids extracted from pepper fruit variety CH-19 Sweet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer mechanisms of capsaicin (from chili pepper), its effects on traditional chemotherapy and radiotherapy, and its potential clinical applications in cancer therapy.
results_summary: Capsaicin demonstrated strong anti-cancer properties, including anti-proliferation, apoptosis induction, and anti-metastasis, with effects varying by concentration and cancer type. It enhanced the efficacy of conventional treatments and capsaicin-loaded nanoparticles showed promise for targeted delivery.
population_specificity: Various cancer types (not specified further).
interactions: Enhanced sensitivity and reduced side effects when combined with chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential health benefits of commonly used spices and herbs, including chili pepper, focusing on their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and disease-preventive properties.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that chili pepper, among other spices, may possess antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and health-protective properties, potentially lowering the risk of chronic diseases like cancer and heart disease. However, the exact role of chili pepper in disease prevention remains unclear.
population_specificity: General population (not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of chili pepper (Capsicum annum) and its bioactive compounds, such as capsaicin, in cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that chili pepper contains bioactive compounds that may induce apoptosis, inhibit tumor proliferation, migration, and invasion, and sensitize tumors to radiotherapy and chemotherapy. These effects suggest potential roles in cancer prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if enjoying spicy foods, particularly those containing capsaicin from chili pepper, could reduce salt preference, salt intake, and blood pressure by altering neural processing of salty taste.
results_summary: The study found that individuals who preferred spicy foods had lower salt intake and blood pressure. Capsaicin enhanced metabolic activity in brain regions associated with salt sensitivity, reducing salt preference and intake in both humans and mice.
population_specificity: Subjects with varying spice preferences, including those who liked and disliked spicy food.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic effects of capsaicin, the active component of chili peppers, on autoimmune diseases by modulating immune responses through TRPV1 activation.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that capsaicin may influence the development and modulation of autoimmune diseases via TRPV1 activation, indicating potential for capsaicin-targeted therapies, though specific outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of autoimmune diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sharing painful experiences, such as eating a hot chili pepper, could promote cooperation and bonding within social groups.
results_summary: The study found that shared painful experiences, including eating a hot chili pepper, increased perceived bonding among strangers and enhanced cooperation in economic games. The results suggest that shared pain can act as a trigger for group formation and trust.
population_specificity: Small groups of participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants were asked to eat a hot chili pepper, but exact amount/frequency not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention duration not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether capsaicin (from chili pepper) increases satiety and reduces energy intake in relation to energy balance.
results_summary: Capsaicin increased satiety and fullness in energy-balanced conditions and tended to reduce overeating during ad libitum intake. It also mitigated the effects of negative energy balance on desire to eat after dinner.
population_specificity: 15 subjects (7 women, 8 men; age 29.7 ± 10.8 years; BMI 23.3 ± 2.9 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 2.56 mg capsaicin (1.03 g red chili pepper, 39,050 Scoville heat units) with every meal.
study_duration: 36-hour sessions (four conditions in a randomized crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers were examining potential environmental triggers, including dietary factors like chili pepper, for the onset or exacerbation of pemphigus vulgaris (PV).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that dietary factors, including red chili pepper, are rare but well-documented triggers for PV, suggesting a possible link between chili pepper consumption and disease onset in genetically predisposed individuals.
population_specificity: Individuals with pemphigus vulgaris (PV) or those genetically predisposed to PV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components and mechanisms of hawthorn leaves in treating myocardial ischemia using network pharmacology, molecular docking, and in vitro experiments.
results_summary: The study identified six active components and 107 potential therapeutic targets, with quercetin, kaempferol, and isorhamnetin as core compounds. Cellular experiments confirmed that quercetin alleviated oxidative damage and regulated key proteins in the PI3K/Akt pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of capsaicin (from chili pepper) on energy expenditure, substrate oxidation, and blood pressure during a 25% negative energy balance.
results_summary: Capsaicin (2.56 mg per meal) counteracted the decrease in energy expenditure components during negative energy balance, promoted fat oxidation, and did not significantly affect blood pressure.
population_specificity: Subjects in a controlled respiration chamber setting (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 2.56 mg capsaicin (1.03 g red chili pepper, 39,050 SHU) with every meal.
study_duration: Four 36-hour sessions (intervention duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an alcohol extract of hawthorn fruit (HAE) on inflammation and oxidative stress in rats with doxorubicin-induced chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: HAE demonstrated cardioprotective effects by improving heart function, reducing cardiac injury markers, and inhibiting inflammatory and oxidative stress responses in CHF rats. It downregulated pro-inflammatory cytokines and upregulated antioxidant enzymes.
population_specificity: Rats with doxorubicin-induced chronic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological effects of Crataegus pinnatifida (Chinese hawthorn) on metabolic syndrome, focusing on its potential benefits for conditions like hyperlipidemia, high blood sugar, obesity, and atherosclerosis.
results_summary: Chinese hawthorn contains active compounds (flavonoids, triterpenic acids, sesquiterpenes) that reduce atherosclerotic lesions, inhibit cholesterol synthesis (lowering VLDL and LDL), and exhibit antithrombotic activity. Studies suggest it may help control metabolic syndrome-related conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanisms by which chitosan improves impaired spermatogenesis in busulfan-treated mice, focusing on gut microbiota and DHA transport.
results_summary: Chitosan improved testicular function and reshaped gut microbiota composition in busulfan-treated mice, reversing DHA transport dysfunction and alleviating ferroptosis in testicular tissues. Fecal microbiota transplantation confirmed the gut microbiota's role in DHA transport and spermatogenesis.
population_specificity: Busulfan-treated mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the polyphenol content of Chinese hawthorn extracts and evaluate their antioxidant and enzyme-inhibitory effects.
results_summary: The study found that hawthorn polyphenol (HP) exhibited strong scavenging capacities for reactive oxygen species (O(2)(-) and (.-)OH) and selective inhibition of prolyl endopeptidase, with procyanidins identified as the likely active constituents. The HP extract had a higher total polyphenol content (21.4%) compared to other extracts.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC(50) values provided: 6.3 µg/ml for O(2)(-), 1.1 µg/ml for (.-)OH, 60 µg/ml for prolyl endopeptidase inhibition)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of sesamol and chitosan nanoparticle-methylcellulose (CSNP-MC) edible coating on moisture loss, oil uptake, oxidation, and PAH levels in deep-fried meatballs.
results_summary: The study found that CSNP-MC edible coating, especially when combined with sesamol, significantly reduced moisture loss, oil uptake, lipid oxidation, protein oxidation, and PAH levels in deep-fried meatballs compared to controls. The SE-CT treatment (sesamol mixed into meat mince with coating) was particularly effective in lowering PAH levels and carcinogenic risk.
population_specificity: Deep-fried meatballs (in vitro study, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carboxymethyl chitosan-dialdehyde glucan/polydopamine carrier-delivered Bacillus subtilis (PBS) could protect against Salmonella-induced intestinal inflammation in mice.
results_summary: PBS significantly reduced inflammation and improved intestinal barrier function by increasing mucin, tight junction proteins, and immune protein expression. It also enhanced beneficial gut flora (Ruminococcus, Bacillus, Roseburia) and short-chain fatty acid levels while inhibiting the TLR4-NF-κB-NLRP3 inflammasome pathway.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Salmonella

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ameliorative effects of chitosan seed priming and foliar application on drought tolerance, yield, and nutritional quality in red kidney beans.
results_summary: Chitosan treatment increased reducing sugars, free amino acids, chlorophyll, proline, and antioxidant enzyme activities while reducing malondialdehyde content. It also enhanced drought tolerance and nutritional quality in red kidney beans.
population_specificity: Red kidney bean plants under induced drought stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chitosan-impregnated cellulose casing could effectively prevent post-processing contamination of ready-to-eat sausages by Listeria monocytogenes and extend shelf-life.
results_summary: The chitosan-impregnated casing reduced L. monocytogenes by 1.50 log CFU/g (~96.8%) within 24 hours in broth media and significantly delayed bacterial growth in inoculated sausages during storage. It also extended the shelf-life of un-inoculated sausages at 4°C and 10°C.
population_specificity: Ready-to-eat sausages (in vitro and in food application).
study_duration: 28 days at 4°C, 5 days at 10°C (for inoculated sausages); 63 days at 4°C, 14 days at 10°C (for un-inoculated sausages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate an injectable chitosan-based hydrogel (CuS/PCS) for treating periodontitis by combining nanoparticles and hydrogels to achieve antibacterial activity and tissue regeneration.
results_summary: The CuS/PCS hydrogel demonstrated high antibacterial activity without bacterial resistance, good biocompatibility, promoted stem cell proliferation, reduced inflammation and bone loss, and enhanced periodontal tissue regeneration in a rat model.
population_specificity: Rat periodontitis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze recent advances in chitosan's chemical and physical modifications to enhance its adsorption performance for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that modifications like crosslinking, nanocomposite synthesis, and magnetic particle incorporation improved chitosan's adsorption capacity, selectivity, and reusability for contaminants like heavy metals, pharmaceuticals, and dyes. Structural-functional correlations, including surface area and thermal stability, were key to optimizing performance.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on material properties, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a plasma-modified Zein/Chitosan composite material for heavy metal (Cu (II) ions) adsorption in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: Plasma-treated Chitosan/Zein composites showed enhanced adsorption capacity (195.14 mg/g for CZ1) for Cu (II) ions, fitting pseudo-second-order kinetics and Langmuir/Freundlich isotherms, indicating spontaneous and exothermic adsorption at low temperatures.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on composite material).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental conditions described, but no duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary chitosan oligosaccharide (COS) supplementation on the gut microbiota of Penaeus vannamei and its potential to enhance beneficial microbes while reducing harmful bacteria.
results_summary: COS supplementation at 5‰ and 10‰ levels significantly increased beneficial microbial taxa (e.g., Bacteroidetes, Actinobacteria) and reduced harmful bacteria like Vibrio parahemolyticus and Vibrio rotiforianus, indicating improved shrimp health and disease resistance.
population_specificity: Penaeus vannamei (Pacific whiteleg shrimp)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chitosan-based polyelectrolyte microparticles for intra-articular delivery of Etoricoxib in managing osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The chitosan-hyaluronic acid microparticles demonstrated high encapsulation efficiency (94.7%) and loading capacity (11.7%), significantly reducing knee joint swelling and inflammatory markers (ALP and IL-6) compared to the drug alone.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal model based on in vivo study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the stability and bioavailability of squid pen hydrolysates (SPTH) using microencapsulation with SP β-chitosan (SPC) and evaluate its targeted release and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study successfully developed SPC-SPTH microcapsules with high encapsulation efficiency, thermal stability, and targeted intestinal release. The encapsulated SPTH showed superior antioxidant activity compared to free SPTH, indicating preserved bioactivity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 2% SPC concentration, 4 mg/mL SPTH concentration, core-to-wall ratio of 1:3 (v/v)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bio-CHNPs could mitigate cadmium chloride toxicity in African catfish by evaluating biochemical, genotoxic, and histopathological effects.
results_summary: Bio-CHNPs treatment reduced CdCl2-induced liver, intestine, and kidney damage, restored antioxidant activity, lowered inflammatory cytokine levels, and decreased DNA damage and micronucleus formation.
population_specificity: African catfish (Clarias gariepinus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a thermosensitive chitosan hydrogel loaded with Thonningianin A nanoparticles could effectively promote diabetic wound healing by addressing oxidative stress and angiogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that the chitosan-based hydrogel (TA-NPs@Gel) exhibited strong antioxidant and angiogenic effects, significantly accelerating wound healing in diabetic mice, likely via the HIF-1 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Diabetic mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate organic hair conditioner formulations based on chitosan-thiadiazole conjugates (CH-ETD and CH-BTD) for their efficacy and safety in hair care.
results_summary: The study found that chitosan-thiadiazole conjugates (CH-ETD and CH-BTD) effectively improved hair conditioning, reducing tangling and enhancing moisture retention, with no signs of irritation. The best-performing formulas (CH, E2, and B2) demonstrated superior hair styling, detangling, and frizz reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general hair care users).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze global research trends, gaps, and contributions in the development of chitosan-mineral composites for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that chitosan-mineral composites are effective, eco-friendly, and cost-effective adsorbents for removing contaminants like heavy metals and dyes, with high academic impact (avg. 32.12 citations per document) and significant international collaboration (26.78%). Key research themes included adsorption mechanisms and composite functionalization, with emerging trends like clay-chitosan synergies and nano-reinforced composites.
population_specificity: Research publications (1690 documents) from the Web of Science (2014–2024).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of carboxymethyl chitosan-modified fluticasone propionate nanosuspensions in a thermo-responsive in situ gel for treating blepharitis.
results_summary: The study found that the chitosan-modified nanosuspensions improved drug solubility and stability, demonstrated long-lasting drug release, and provided notable therapeutic benefits in a blepharitis rat model, including reduced inflammation and improved tear secretion. The formulation also showed good biocompatibility in cytotoxicity and irritation tests.
population_specificity: Rat model of blepharitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize a non-animal sourced chitosan scaffold for wound healing applications and assess its effectiveness in combination with xeno-free human umbilical cord mesenchymal stromal cells under macromolecular crowding conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the non-animal sourced chitosan scaffold had appropriate structural and mechanical properties for wound healing, and neither the scaffold nor macromolecular crowding negatively impacted cell metabolic activity or proliferation. However, in vivo results showed no significant differences in wound closure or scar size between treatment groups.
population_specificity: Human umbilical cord mesenchymal stromal cells (in vitro) and a splinted nude mouse wound healing model (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the preparation methods and applications of chitosan-based hydrogel beads in food preservation, medicine, and environmental protection.
results_summary: Chitosan-based hydrogel beads exhibit excellent biocompatibility, antibacterial properties, and a dense structure suitable for encapsulating bioactive substances and adsorbing impurities, making them effective in tissue engineering, drug delivery, and wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a chitosan-based hydrogel dressing (CS/GP/Cu3SnS4) with antibacterial properties and biocompatibility to enhance burn wound healing.
results_summary: The CS/GP/Cu3SnS4 hydrogel demonstrated strong antibacterial effects (>95% against S. aureus and E. coli), good biocompatibility, and superior wound healing performance in vivo compared to controls.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo experiments, no human subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review stabilization strategies for chitosan-based nanomedicines and their applications in cancer therapy, particularly for drug delivery.
results_summary: The study found that chitosan-based nanomedicines face stability issues in physiological conditions but highlighted stabilization strategies like chemical modifications and complexation with metal ions or anionic polymers. It also emphasized their potential in cancer therapy through improved drug delivery.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a chitosan/pullulan composite edible coating with thyme essential oil nanoemulsion to enhance antifungal and preservative properties for extending strawberry shelf life.
results_summary: The chitosan/pullulan coating with thyme essential oil nanoemulsion significantly reduced Botrytis cinerea growth (54.7% inhibition rate) and improved strawberry preservation, with C50/P50/T-treated samples showing the lowest weight loss and decay incidence after 12 days.
population_specificity: Strawberries (in vitro and in vivo preservation study)
effective_dosage: 2% thyme essential oil nanoemulsion incorporated into chitosan/pullulan coatings (various ratios: C100, C100/T, C75/P25/T, C50/P50/T, C25/P75/T)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a chitosan-based hydrogel with enhanced mechanical and antibacterial properties for potential use in dye wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the chitosan-based hydrogel exhibited improved mechanical properties (7.44-fold increase in hardness) and notable antibacterial effects against E. coli and S. aureus, along with effective dye adsorption capacities (157.23 mg/g for methylene blue and 79.15 mg/g for Congo red).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations of silver ammonia solution and zinc chloride varied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 9 weeks of Citrulline plus beetroot extract supplementation on maximal and endurance-strength performance and aerobic power in male triathletes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study was designed to evaluate the combined effects of Citrulline and beetroot extract on performance metrics in endurance athletes.
population_specificity: Male triathletes
